speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next today in Case No. 14-103, Baker Botts v. ASARCO. Mr. Streett.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, the principle basis, as I understand it, is that when you prepare it, you're -- you're serving the -- the trustee.  You're serving his needs but when, you know, if he's disallowing it, you're, to the contrary, acting against the trustee's interest.  Isn't that a principle distinction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay So you'd acknowledge it's okay if the trustee objects, then he doesn't have to pay, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I didn't think you would.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the trustee is not the estate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The estate wants to keep as much money as it can to give to the creditors. That's the purpose, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If you hired another law firm to fight this objection, would that other law firm have been entitled to fees too?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I just want to understand your rule completely.  Anybody who prepares a fee application -- an accountant, an expert -- the bankruptcy court can pay all of their legal fees, if the trustee has hired their lawyer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Approved their lawyer? But if the trustee hasn't, then they have to assume the costs of fighting --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I take it you -- excuse me.  If the trustee objects and there's a lengthy hearing, I take it you would still say that you get fees for participating in that hearing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.  So the fact that ASARCO came in is really irrelevant to the -- to this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That was in the context of a fee splitting statute though.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but just -- on the parity point, if you're not doing bankruptcy work and you send the client a bill and they don't pay it, if you've got to take litigation action or whatever, you Alderson Reporting Company don't get paid -- you don't get those fees back.  We follow the normal American rule and you pay your own fees and if you win, good; if not, you don't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Streett, do you have a position on enhancements?  If -- if the creditors say that enhancement is -- you did a good job but it's not worth the enhancement, is defending the enhancement also, under your rule, compensable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You practice in bankruptcy. I mean, you know it pretty well because what I was trying to think of, which is really balancing on the side, but the phrase "likely to benefit," it has -- it says "likely to benefit." Now, it seems to me there must be instances where you, representing the -- the debtor, hire accountants or various others to do technical work, conveying and where -- where, in fact, it's quite clear that it won't mean more money for the debtor.  It will mean less money for the debtor, because it will discover all kinds of assets  they didn't even think the debtor had, but that's part of your job.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you do it and it Alderson Reporting Company benefits only the creditor.  And I take it, it's rather clear, you get compensated for that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that right?  Am I just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, then you're in trouble, because if -- if all those things -- I mean, there are a set of things, such that when you carry them out through accountants or conveyers or others, will in fact cost the estate a lot of money.  Possibly more than they ever dreamt.  And yet it's part of your job.  Now, if that's not considered as being  of benefit to the estate, but rather, part of the administration of the estate, then I don't see how this falls within benefit to the estate.  I mean, if you're really making that distinction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If that's administration of the estate, then this would have to be administration of the estate.  But this isn't administration of the estate, and therefore, it's left out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, you're saying this is administration.  In other words, you're not saying it falls within (a).  You're saying it falls within (b).

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I see.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're ignoring one important aspect of difference which is in everything else, you're acting for the estate.  When you're defending fees, you're acting for yourself.  There is a self-interest involved because you could just give up on the objections and walk away.  The only reason you're fighting them is because it puts more money in your pocket.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Not because it puts more money in the estate's pocket.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, except that preparing the fee application:  A, it's specifically allowed by statute; and B, if they compensate you for that, there's -- then you'll do a very careful job, and there will be less necessity to have to defend it.  So it -- so there --  it is certainly a rational reason Alderson Reporting Company for the distinction.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But people know -- I mean, the American rule in the legal area is very fundamental, and it strikes me bankruptcy is one of those areas where they go into considerable detail telling you who pays what and when you can get it, just like you say here.  You get compensation for preparing the fee at this particular level.  And to say that somewhere in -- in all this, you sort of cut and paste these things together and you say, oh, there it shows that they meant fees on fees to be awarded.  It seems to me that if they wanted to go against the basic American rule --  thatâ€™s the American rule, patriotic -- they would have -- they would have spelled that out a little more clearly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Fletcher.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where does it fall within the (4)(A)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If it's not subject to (4)(A) at all -- I mean, (4)(A) forbids certain -- it says you can't -- cannot allow compensation for, and then, you know, it has the list there.  So -- so how do you -- where do you find the authority to give this to them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So where -- where is the authorization to give it then?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where does it say that you can get the money that's necessary for you to get the -- the money you pay to get the reasonable compensation. Where does it say you get that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Well, then, I mean, suppose that you had to go through enormous trouble to get what they paid you.  They paid you and you -- you know, some kind of Voltavian bonds or something -- you know, you  imagine all kinds of circumstances where it costs a lot of money to get the money they paid you, and I just wonder where does it say you can do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So why isn't that in the administration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why -- I'm sorry.  Go ahead. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Sounds like a policy judgment.  You're basically saying it's not in the statute, but this is how we do it and as Justice -- as the Chief Justice pointed out, normal attorneys outside the bankruptcy court don't get compensated for fee disputes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why isn't the problem here better dealt with by sanctions?  If a party like ASARCO makes frivolous objections, then they -- then sanctions can be imposed on them.  And the -- the fees fall on the party that caused the problem rather than on the estate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No more so than -- than the -- the lawyer who submits a bill outside of bankruptcy to a client, and the client objects, and the lawyer has to -- has to litigate.  Would you say that dilutes the lawyer's recovery?  No, I assume that the lawyer's fees are set at a high enough level that it -- that they take into account the fact that sometimes you will have to litigate to get the fees.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And why can't bankruptcy lawyers do the same thing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What was your reason for not going with the administration of the estate?  And my intuitive judgment of it, which is pretty not totally informed, of course, is there -- there are loads of things that -- that -- that lawyers do who represent a trustee -- who represent debtors, that it will cost the estate a lot of money.  And you can't say all of them are for the benefit of the estate.  And there are loads of things they do to help administer the estate and hire all kinds of people.  And -- and paying their fees is part of the administration, I would think, normally. Why don't you see the paying of the lawyer as part of the administration of the estate?  And if you see the part -- that part as part of the administration of the estate, then you'd see that the administrative expenses necessary to secure that payment are part of the administration. I mean, so you had some reason over there in the Justice Department of saying, no, we don't follow Alderson Reporting Company that route, and -- and I'm not.  And so that -- of course, that creates a difficulty because I think, well, if your judgment is don't follow that route, then I -- I better be careful about following it myself.  And -- and you know more about it in a sense, so -- so explain that to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, I understand your argument, and all know that's true about it.  I just wonder you're -- you're studying this.  You're trying to develop a position.  And for some reason or other, you rejected what the -- what they started out with that this falls within 4(A)(ii) -- (i) or (ii), and I wondered why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know that.  I already knew -- can see that.  I just wondered why --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- you -- you rejected. You had a reason for not doing what seems linguistically the simplest thing and say it is part of the administration.  And you had a reason, and I want to know what the reason is, if you can tell us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The administration of the case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Service.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Ah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is -- is there another part that says it's service to the estate rather than service to the case or something like that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Render --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.  I see. Thank you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Oldham.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So how does the fee fit into this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The -- the fee, the fee -- the fee preparation fee.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Oldham, why aren't they all tied together so you recognize that the application for the fee is compensable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's like the opening pleading.  Then the objection is the answer to the application, and then the response to the objection is the -- the defense of it.  It seems to me it's -- it's all one package, that it -- the application, and there's an answer to the application, and then there's a reply. It -- why don't those three things go together?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do lawyers these days actually charge private clients for fee preparation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I've -- I've been Alderson Reporting Company out of practice for half a century, but my -- my -- my thought was that -- that -- that lawyers do -- do charge for the amount of time preparing the bill.  Maybe I'm wrong about that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: We can -- we can check it out.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You ought to think -- might want to think about it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is -- is there any writing that says that when lawyers, outside bankruptcy, determine their -- their fee structures, that they include reimbursement for the risk that they might have to go into court to defend it?  I've never heard that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: On that theory, if -- I mean, if -- if you're supposed to get some fees -- say, $100,000 -- and in that fee is -- is various risks of the extra money it'll cost to collect or the extra risk of you won't get it, you'll only get half and -- and you -- you set the rate at 100,000. And so now a different risk is eventuated -- namely, you had to go to litigation -- and that wasn't in the 100,000.  Well, then, if it's reasonable and everything, why shouldn't it be? I mean, why is -- you're -- you're trying to, in that 100,000, give the employer something for their -- for their time and their effort and also Alderson Reporting Company compensate certain risks.  And here was one that wasn't in the  100,000.  It turned up later.  But how would you draw a line between some and the other?  I think that's the government's theory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, no, of course, it doesn't exist -- you're quite right -- outside of bankruptcy. But now you're saying that the 100,000 does include all kinds of -- for various payments for things that might make it more expensive to get the money.  And then what I don't see is saying some and not others.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And this is just one of them, I mean, the -- that you have to go into court and litigate, is just one of them.  You wouldn't object, for example, if the fee -- the judge says, look.  We're going to give the firm 120, why not 100? Well, you know, there are risks in this; and one of the risks is they're going to have to go to court Alderson Reporting Company and somebody will sue them and they have to go litigate that.  So we'll give it to them upfront to pay for the risk, just as you pay for the risk of nonpayment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Because?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no.  It's -- it's not. Only -- actually, only 90 is.  But it's reasonable compensation because 10 compensates for risks such as risks of nonpayment. Am I being clear?        Do you see where I'm going?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Maybe this is not worth pursuing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And that was -- that was Alderson Reporting Company my question.  Can you tell me, if -- if a distinguished law firm represents a trustee in bankruptcy, does the law firm charge its regular rate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The same rate that it would charge to a -- to a non-bankruptcy client.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In the papers --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Oldham, you -- you agree, don't you, that in this system, the court can do enhancements?  Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yeah.  So some of the things that we've said are permissible for enhancements are exceptional delays in payment, extraordinary outlays of expenses, and unusually protracted litigation -- okay? -- that those count as enhancements.  We said that in Alderson Reporting Company Perdue v. Kenny A.  Why isn't this just like that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No, no, no.  But I'm proceeding on the assumption of -- on the SG's assumption that what we're trying to do is to get a reasonable rate for the services that clearly have been authorized.  And the question is:  What's a reasonable rate? And it seems to me that what this statute does is to say "reasonable" can include, like, lots of things.  It's highly discretionary.  Right? And then on top of that, you know, it -- included in "what is reasonable" is this idea of sometimes you can do performance enhancements, but we haven't said performance enhancements are just for super-duper work.  We've actually said performance enhancements are for things like unusually protracted Alderson Reporting Company litigation and lots of expenses and exceptional delays, sort of like this. You know, this is just an expense of your work, is having to go after the fees.  So why doesn't that get into the mix, too?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No, it does, because the text just says "reasonable."  And then the question is what's reasonable?  And "reasonable" can include, you know, you're getting the same hourly rate as some other lawyer, but "reasonable" is, also, you had to do this over a very extended period of time and "reasonable" is, also, boy, you had to spend a lot of money in order to get them to pay you anything at all.  All of those things count as what's part of "reasonable."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yeah, it's reasonable for all the other work you're doing.  But then everything else goes into this question of reasonable, right? Is -- you know, I'll give you a hypothetical. Suppose I hire somebody to shovel my driveway, and I say, I'm going to give you reasonable compensation.  And everybody knows that it's $10 an hour to hire my driveway, right?  That's the going rate. But then I say, oh, did I not tell you -- did I not tell you I'm going to make you go down -- come down to the court so that I can pay you the $10?  And that costs another $5.  All right? Now, it strikes me that if somebody said, what's reasonable compensation now, it would be $15.  It wouldn't be $10.  And it's the exact same thing here. It's like by the time you go through all this stuff that you have to go through to get paid, you should get paid more.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But it doesn't say you can't get paid for it.  There's no exclusion.  All, you know -- you know, I think you and the SG agree, it's -- we're not counting this as the service.  What we're saying is you have to be reasonably paid for the obvious services that you have performed, shoveling my driveway. And in my -- in my hypothetical, that means you also have to be paid for the cab fare.  And similarly, here, it means you also have to be paid for the cost of, like, making them sign a check to you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, it doesn't have to go be- -- I mean, I just don't understand what that means. Alderson Reporting Company It's this -- it's the clear service rendered, it's shoveling my driveway, it's doing the work for the estate.  What counts as reasonable?  What counts as reasonable is not just the hourly rate, but all the things I've put you through to get the hourly rate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But here's the problem, I think, with that response.  It's a reasonable response, but we're already out of the American rule here.  I mean, the bankruptcy system puts you in a different universe than a statutory universe, and the question is what do those words of the statute say?  It's not what would exist if the statute didn't exist.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, the American rule can't trump the statute.  The statute has to trump the American rule.  And if the statute says reasonable compensation for services rendered -- the obvious services rendered, and -- and the only thing that counts as reasonable is taking into account things like how protracted the litigation is and how much risk you've had and the exceptional delay, and the fact that you've had to contest a lot, a lot, a lot of meritless objections, all of those things make for something -- go into the question of what's reasonable.  They don't have to.  I mean, in 90 percent of the cases, it might be that it's like, no, that's just a normal part of the process.  But in that other 10 percent, where it's not a normal part of the process and you wouldn't be reasonably paid unless they were included, it seems to me the word reasonable demands that they be included.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What about other statutes? I was thinking the same thing, there are other statutes that provide -- that undo the American rule, and they say you're entitled, if you're victorious, to reasonable attorney's fees.  Do they usually include fees for getting the fees?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you practice in bankruptcy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Do you practice in Alderson Reporting Company bankruptcy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And do you happen to know whether fee litigation is more common in bankruptcy than  other fields?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, all right, but if you Alderson Reporting Company look at the fee-shifting statutes, we looked up a lot, we found quite a few which say that the court can award a reasonable attorney's fee.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's broader than here. But the words, basic active words are reasonable attorney's fees, and almost all of them have been interpreted to allow compensation for the reasonable fee.  So they throw that in.  And so, they're counting it as part of the reason -- they're counting it as part of a reasonable attorney's fees.  And here, reasonable attorney's fee is the same.  That language is the same.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: A reasonable compensation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There is a reasonable attorney's fee.  But it's hard to make a lot out of that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that happens later, everything's closed and they discover that through some odd thing they have to spend $10,000 to get the $90,000 that was awarded to them.  Any authority on that?  You go back to court and say, Judge, I want $10,000 more. He says, But the case was closed.  He says, Yeah, but I but to spend the $10,000 to get the $90,000.  If there were such a case, one of you would have found it.  Or somebody would have, I guess.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But there's no -- just under all these other statutes, there is so many attorney's fees statutes that --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Streett, four minutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Will you answer his last point?  Why does it make any sense to say that the lawyer can get -- make his fee reasonable by getting his litigation expenses, but the accountant, who's also entitled to reasonable fees, cannot?  If he has to sue, he has to pay his own lawyer, and you don't assert that that -- that that is compensable, do you? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, you do?  Okay.  I didn't realize you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I thought you said earlier the trustee had to approve it.  And I'm wondering how the trustee could approve that, because it's for the benefit of the accountant,  not the trust.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Are there case authorities supporting the answers you gave?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It does eat those costs. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Except -- except that in Woods, looking at the predecessor statute, which also talked about services rendered, we held that the phrase "reasonable compensation for services rendered," quote, this is us, "necessarily implies loyal and disinterested service in the interest of those for whom the claimant purported to act."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How do you answer the question about suppose the objection to the fee is sustained?  Does the lawyer, nonetheless, get the work?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
